document.text: We in Appomattox have always felt that the people liv ing in and around Gladstone, although across from the Appo mattox side of the historic James River, have much more in common with us than with either Amherst or Nelson counties. As a link to bind this friendship, high school pupils from Gladstone attend the Appomattox Agricultural high school. Buses bring the mevery day and they form an integral part of the school body. Recently a meeting of the Gladstone community league was aeld and we understand that the patrons voted to send their pupils here another year, rather than to a high school in their own county. We in Appomattox want to show our gratitude for thi spirit of our neighbors along the James. They are always wel ome here and we value their friendship and support. ---------------------O---------------------

Several counties attempted to secure i the high school but Congressrrian Flood and several local people worked to have it located here in Appomattox. Mr. L. Crawley, a Virginian who had experience with agricultural high schools in Georgia was employed, as principal.

document.text: The 1926 graduating class of Appomattox Agricultural High School celebrated its fiftieth reunion Saturday evening with a dinner at the old high school cafeteria. Of the twenty-seven surviving members, 22 weire present, eight with their spouses. An open house get together was held from 430 to 630 at the home of Mrs. Florence Trent. After the meal, Mrs. Onida OBrien Persinger held at memorial for the twelve deceased class members. Three teachers, June Hubbard Knight, Miss Edith Kruger, and Mrs. Helen Welch Harvey were recognized. Each class member gave a capsule report of his 50 years since graduation. Message from absent members and teachers were given by Phoebe OBrien McGill. A most enjoyable occasion with the Spirit Of 76.   f  _ ,  ... _ Attending, pictured above were, front row from left, Hazel Mann, Dan Jennings, Lucille t. Puckett, Helen Harvey, Cornell Pugh, Edith Kruger, and June H. Knight second row from left, Alice H. Marshall, Ouida 0. Persinger, Myrtle E. Duffher, Olive L. Pearce, Ursula W. Davis, Vara M. Robertson. Nell C. Thrasher, Gladys J. Harvey, and third row from left, Phoebe OB. McGdl, Virginia W. Reams, Catherine C. Deane, Florence G. Trent, Kate P. Cummings, Catherine G. Frazier, Gladys Dudley and Rebecca M. Jamerson.

document.text: The 1921 graduating class of the Appomattox Agricultural High School celebrated their fifty-fifth reunion Saturday evening with a dinner party at Maudes Restaurant. The group, a number of whom were accompanied by their spouses, came to the home of Mrs. Rachel F. Lawson and visited before the dinner. After the dinner they visited and reminisced in the home of Mr. and Mrs, Reggie Stanley. In the photo above, standing, are Joe Clark, Reggie Stanley, and J. Metteau Carr and seated, Mrs. Rachel F. Lawson, Miss Nola M. Burkey, Mrs. Frances Street Carter, Gaines Oglesby and Mrs. Verta Smith Stanley. Mr. and Mrs. Joe Clark of Danville were week end guests of Mr. and Mrs. R. W. Stanley, and Mr. and Mrs. J. Metteau of Oxford, N.C. were guests of Mrs. Lawson.

document.text: Scholarship. Prof. L Orawley, Agricultural High School, Appomattox, Va. My dear Sir President Alderman has request ed me to remind yon that yoni ex cellent school has the right to award a sc noia rah ip in the College of this University, for next session, to one of yoar 1915 graduates. To win suoh a scholarship is, ot oonrae, a high honor and that fact should be made dear to your students. We hope therefore that yon will be kind enough to bring the matter to the attention of the young men who will graduate from your sohool at the end of tfie present session and that you and your faculty will fin ally oonfer the scholarship upon one whose career will reflect oredit upon the University, as well aa up on your school. We hope that the scholarship will be conferred during your graduating exercises and that due notice of it will appear in your local papera. Also I snail appreoi ate it if you will sen u me, as soon as practicable, the name of the holder. J. M. P age , Dean, University of Virginia.

document.text: John K irk Hannah John Kirk Hannah died in Norfolk, Va., after a lingering illness, on Thursday, January 19th, 1922. Mr. Hannah was born at  Ridgeway , near Appomattox O. H , Va., on February 18tb, 1842, the son of the late William Morton Hannah and Mary Richardson Hannah, of Appo mattox county, and was in his eightieth year. He waa married in 1865 to Miss Ella K. Watkins, who died in 1903. The greater part of Mr. Han nahs life was spent in his native county as a farmer, where he was well known and beloved by all. He was educated at Hampden Sidney College, leaving that institution at the age of nine teen to enter the Confederate aftoy in 1861. He served with the Staunton Hill Artillery until the surrender in 1865 Returning to his old home Mr. Hannah at once took up bis share of the burden of uplift iog his county from the desper ate condition forced npon it by the ravages of a cruel war. He was especially interested in school work, and for eigb teen years served as a trustee. Later be was elected Superin tendent of schools of bis coun ty, which position be filled for sixteen yeais. During bis ad ministration, aud largely due to his efforts, the Appomattox Agricultural High school waB founded and he never lost in terest in this institution, even after leaving the county. Im paired vision caused him to re sign as Superintendent of cbools in 1913, and thereafter be made his home with hi daughter at Charlotte Court House, and later in 1918 in Norfolk. Daring his whole life, Mr. Hannah was a devoted and sincere Christian, having been a member of the Presbyterian church for more than sixty years. For ten years he served as a deacon and for forty years as an elder in the ohnrohes whioh he attended. Though afflicted in later years by s failing eyesight that all but blottea the light of day from him, he bore it with a patience and fortitude whioh command ed the admiration and respect of everyone who knew him. document.text: Greetings from Martha St. Mostly I am up by 6 a.m. and shortly thereafter venture over town to fetch the morning papas and see what is in prospect for the day. Tother morning I had to slow down to give road crossing privileges to a tiny rabbit. Little Bunny was in no hurry and neither was I, and that was that. Later on I saw a cat stepping fast to avoid a menacing jaybird. And when I say Appomattox is a Growing and a Busy Town, that is what I mean. Traffic is continuous and there is no hour of the day or night you can venture forth without traffic. Ah yes, and that is good. The big trucks, the tourists with their trailers, workers hastening to punch the shift timedocks, shoppers, and those just riding around. Seventy-six is a BIG year.    I was discouraging morning glories and honeysuckle in my garden area when I discovered a well-hidden birds nest in a shrub-1 let it be. I think there is some activity in a few of my watermelon hills and I have hope that some of the cotton seed I planted will make it. But the big garden item right now is the bringing in of beautiful gladiolus. Had one big red that measured forty six inches. And I am reasonably sure that whats coming up next to wbpre the lettuce was is sunflowers  M    1 was ...one. of jflee ordered the advertised Living Flag, which was said to from especially arranged seed tapes into a USA flag by His Fourth of July. Well, it i up and growing, on the bank of my front lawn, but may be late with the flowering. W    Time marches ..sin. Yes it does. And with it, some, landmarks of yesteryear yield to the bulldozer and scoop. For example, the old Dormitory at the school on Church Street. It is coming down, and with it memories precious to many former students. Appomattox Agricultural High School at-

The Senior class will present their play Friday night, June 6th,. The Miss Kate Franklinc class, will Miss Kate Franklins class, will give its program June 7th. All the exercises will take place in the high school auditorium, ex cept the baccalaureate sermon which will be delivered Sunday evening at 8 oclock in Liberty Baptist church. document.text: By FRANCES PAULETTE A host of family, friends, co-workers and school officials gathered in the cafeteria of the Appomattox Primary School on Monday, May 30, to honor Mrs. Dora L. Evrod Conner, who is retiring after 17 years as a member of the APS cafeteria staff. Dora and I have shared many happy years together, said Mrs. Annie Laurie Babcock, long time friend and a retired co-worker. Doras association with the school system goes back to 1952 when she worked with Mrs. Babcock at the old Appomattox High School. She was a part of that cafeteria staff for eight years. In 1960 Conner began working with Poe Hardware Co. and remained there unto 1966. Doras love of children prompted her to return to work with the school system this time in the cafeteria at Appomattox Primary School. We first started our work together when we were at the old high school with 12 grades, said Babcock with a smile. We cooked on a coal burning stove with ashes, soot and smoke it was especially bad on Monday mornings. But, we never failed to have lunch on time. Dora Abbitt Conner, the daugh ter of the late Mr. and Mrs. George Francis Abbitt Sr. was born at Gravel Knoll, the Abbitt property formerly known as the Ola Webb Place. Along with the family of six, Dora attended New Hope Baptist Church, going to and from the services in a Model T. Ford. Still an active member of the same church, she is active in Sunday School, WMU, Outreach, and other church related activities. Being a good neighbor and doing for others comes naturally to Dora Conner .... shes always been a caring person. A younger brother commented on her cuing attitude. Doras always been a caring person, always caring about other people, commented Herbert Ab bitt, a local pharmacist. When we were little, I could always count on Dora to be my protector! Abbitt commented with a laugh. Dora C onnerattended  Vera Elementary School and Appomattox Agricultural High School later it became Appomattox High School. She was valedictorian of her graduating class. In order to attend classes at the high school, Dora had to live during

document.text: Appom attox A gricultural H igh School Com m encem ent.  The Commencement exercises of the Appomattox Agricultural High School commenced last 8nnday evening. Notwithstanding the in clemency of the weather quite a large crowd assembled in the Audi torium to hear Dr. Geo. B. Taylor, who delivered a very excellent ad dress to the graduating class on a very practical subject. The singing of the pupils was quite a feature of the evening. One very gratifying feature about the management of the Commence ment exeroises is that no time hM been taken from the class room studies. The Principal states that not a minrite hM been lost irom class work. This is very pleMing to many of the parents since much time has been lost during the ses sion on account of sicknesB. The graduating class is large and is composed of nine sweet, attractive young ladies and two bots. The personal of the class is as follows Mr, J. Gills, Mr. Geo. Tames, Miss Louise Gills, Miss Marv Bab cock, Miss Venona Sears, Miss Eto hel Abbitt, Miss Gracie Hancock, Miss Cabell Foster, Miss Jacqueline Atwood, Miss Fannie Taylor and Miss Lyuolie Atwood. document.text: AND DOWN CAME THE OLD DORMITORY -In 1915, at an approximate cost of 10,000, the dormitory at the Appomattox Agricultural High School was built to house teachers and students from the area who wished to attend school but due to limited transportation in those days were unable to make the trip daily. Later when the school became Appomattox High School, then Appomattox County High School, it was used for classroom space, for music room, textbook office and prior to the building of the new Appomattox County High School was mainly uesed for office suites for the Guidance Department with the basement being utilized by the Athletic Department as shower ami locker rooms. Through the years, the old dormitory deteriorated to the point it could no longer be used, was unsafe, and was not feasible to try and restore the budding thus the décision was made to tern- it down. The old building served a purpose for many a year but when workmen started Wednesday of last week it took only a matter of a few days to demolish the old dorm.

document.text: Nathan Smith, representing the Appomattox Senior FFA Chapter won the Hub Federation Tractor Operators contest. The contest was held on March 23 at Rustburg Middle School. The contest consisted of backing and pulling a two wheel trailer, backing a four wheel wagon, and tractor maintenance trouble shooting. Safety, accuracy,and time are scored. Nathan earned the best score in each of the three events. This win entitles Nathan to compete in the Southside Area contest May 1. . Nathan and the Appomattox County High School Agricultural Department would like to thank Mr. Jack Caldwell and Appomattox Truck and Tractor for the use of their tractor and Mrs. Henry Pack, Brod Pack, and George Perdue for the use of their trailer.

document.text: Appomattox County Youth Displaces Frank Brockman, Of Amherat. Lynchburg.According to an an nouncement made here, the Boys Corn Club champion for 1913 goes to four teen-year-old Henry Odor, of Appomat tox county, who produced ten bushels more of corn to the acre than any other member in any of the counties which were contesting for this honor. Young Odor, displaces Frank Brock man, the Amherst, county champion, from that honor, and he is to have a trip to Washington, as well as to get all the prizes offered in the State for the achievement. Young Odor pro duced from an acre 154 bushels of white corn by measurement, or 156 bushels by actual weight. The new champion has been a student at the Appomattox Agricultural and High School for three or four years, and for two years won the county prizes.

document.text: There will be a free weding dem onstration next Friday, May 8, at 730 P. M. at the Agricultural Shop at Appomattox High School. Farm shop class members, veterans class members, farmers and all others in terested ars invited to attend the dem ent JTba which will be spon sored byHaacoito Electric represen tatives. TG 3 fsnt should be of in terest to all conesraed with the re pair and maintenance ot farm equipment. Dick Stratton, factory representa tive of Lincoln Electric H. S. Jones Jr. and J. 0. Moore, of the Dabney Foundry A Machhae Works, Lynch burg, will give n e demonstration. It is arranged in cooperation with H. B. Pack, Jr., vocational agricul ture instructor. A new 180 amp welder will he featured, to operate from power take-off on tractor. A new outstand ing arc torch will also be demon strated, which enables one to heat metal with electric welder. Similar demonstrations were re cently held at Rustburg and Alta vista. The rapid increase in the use of farm machinery has made it most desirable for farmers to make a study of repair and maintenance, so a large number should be present next Friday at 730.

document.text: The Appomattox t ounty High School Agricultural Ed ucation Department will open its shop on November 15, 1972, to begin its regular farm mechanics classes. These classes will be held Wednesday and Thursday of each week from 630 p.m. until 1000 p.m. There will be an opportunity during these classes for wood working, metal work, and welding. An enrollment fee of 1.50 will be required of each person participating. For further information, contact the high school Agri cultural Education Depart ment.

document.text: Mr. Henry B. Pack, Agricultural Instructor of Appomattox High School, is serving on the Rules Com mittee of a nationwide high school 7,000 Arc Welding Award Program sponsored by the James F. Lincoln Arc Welding Foundation of CU-vc land Ohio. The purpose ol the essay contest, he states, is to encourage high school students to study how arc welding can contribute to bettei farm operation and maintenance. Mr. Pack says that although the competition is nation-wide, entries are not received in such large quanti t i e s that students should feel they do not have a chance. He feels that students in Virginia have an excel lent chance to receive some of the 100 awards to be made, ranging from 25 to 600. He urges all in the state who are interested to write to the Foundation, Cleveland 17, Ohio, for a copy of the rules booklet. This booklet contains 61 pictures of pro jects which received awards in pre vious programs. I.ast year there were no awards in the State of Virginia.  1 Awards are made for the best de- ! scriptions of how arc welding can he or was used to make a school oi I home project. document.text: Mr. and Mrs. James W. Bondurant, Route 2, Concord, were presented the 1975 Outstanding Young Farmer Family Award for the South- side Area in a ceremony Friday evening, November 21, at the Annual Convention of the Southside Area Young Farmers and Young Homemakers held in the Halifax County High School. Bondurant is a member of the Appomattox Young Farmers Association. The Bondurants were pre sented with an engraved silver tray and a certificate from the Virginia Bankers Association. Presentation was made on behalf of the bankers of Virginia by W. A. Hunter, Vice President and Cashier, Farm ers National Bank, Appomat tox, in recognition of the importaqce of agriculture to Virginias economy. Six area awards and the State award are sponsored by the Virginia Bankers Associa tion in cooperation with the Young Farmers of Virginia Association, an organization of the State Department of Education. Bondurant, 22, received the American Farmer Degree in 1974. He completed four years of agricultural education at Appomattox High School and is now a member of the Future Farmers of America Alumni and the American Hereford Association. Jim and Kay Bondurant are active in church, agriculture, and civic organiza tions. As the Southside Area winner, the Bondurants will compete with five other area winners for the Outstanding Young Farmer Family of Virginia award to be presented in February. document.text: Under the expert - supervision of professor Virgil H. Gill, an excellent shop has gradually been equipped, in the agricultural department of the Appomattox high school. Realizing the demand for and the trend towaids practical vocation al training, the work shop has grown until it now is one of the most pop ular and most useful forms of study at the local school. Starting with an appropriation of 361 four years ago, professor nas accumulated val uable machine equipment and tools. Sixty-two boys are- taking the shop course. We inspected the de partment this week and found a large class of boys busy on a wide variety of handicraft. We iHound Hunt Hamilton and E. D. Jones making a wheelbarrow. A chicken house record box occupied .Charlie lUines and Hurley Trent. Jack Mar tin had several boys helping him at work on a baby bed. Another boy was making a handle for a ham mer. Another had finished a what not and there were completed, book racks, tables etc. Someone.. had brought in a cider press to be re paired . Professor Gill says fie likes for the boys to make practical things for use around the farm and home. Materials are furnished at cost. The shop hope to get more and heavier equipment this fall. document.text: Mr. and Mrs. Norman Booth, RFD 1, Spout Spring, were presented the 1961 Outstand ing Young Farmer Faauly Award for the Southside Area during the Annual Young Farmer Area Convention at the Appomattox County High Sc hool, Thursday, November 19. Norman is a member of the Appomattox Young Farmers Association. The Booths were presented an engraved silver tray from the Virginia Bankers Associa tion and a check for 100 from the Farmville Farm Credit Services Association. The che ck was awarded by Susan Ennis, Office Manager of the Farmville Office. William Hun ter, Farmers National Bank, Appomattox, representing the Virginia Bankers Association, presented the tray. Norman completed five years of agricultural education in the Appomattox High School and earned the Virginia State Farmer Degree. Mr. and Mrs. Booth are active in many agriculture, church, and civic organizations. As Southside Area winners, the Booths will compete with five other winners for the. O utstanding Young .Farm er Family of Virginia award February. Counties in the Southside Area competition are Amelia, Amherst, Appomattox, Bed ford, Buckingham, Campbell, Charlotte, Cumberland. document.text: The Appomattox and Pamplin School Community Canneries will begin opera tion Tuesday., July 8, for the 1979 canning season, accord ing to LJoyd 6. Walton, -superintendent of schools for Appoihattox County. In an effort to conserve fuel, the canneries w ill,, operate only on Tuesdays of.., eadfWfeeltVat the begin of the ciHhing seakbt. JAs f volume increases, more days of the week will be used for canning purposes. The can neries will be closed for all j legal holidays-Labor Day and Thanksgiving. Patrons may call the canneries for information on days of operation. The telephone number for the Pamplin Cannery is 248-6191 , and the number for the Appomattox Cannery is 352-2222. f Each cannery, will begin food processing at 800 a.m. each .day that the cannery is in operation. Families are requested to bring in food between the hours of 800 - 1230, and have all foods ready for processing by 100 p.m. Since only a limited amount of utensils are available at the cannery, patrons are requested to bring necessary clothes, pans, knives, etc. for preparing foods for process ing. Lay instructors sod other supervisory personnel will be availqble to instruct patrons in the use of cannery equipment as well as to demonstrate proper canning procedures. Children under 12 years of age are not allowed on cannery premis es. D etailed rules and procedures for using the canneries will be given to each patron when they register to use the cannery facilities. Patron cooperation in following these procedur es will greatly help  in producing quality processed foods , Can prices have been advanced this year because of a price increase in fuel oil  and other m aintenance costs. Prices which have been set by tht School Board are as follows Number 303 pint 17 cents Number 2V quart 23 cents Number 10 55 cents It is anticipated that the- canneries in Appomattox County will have an ade- quate supply of cans, j Lay instructors at the Appomattox Cannery will be Grace Williams and William Guthrie with Mr. Barry F. document.text: A class in farm mechanics will begin Monday night, Jan. 24, at the shop in the Pamplin Ele mentary School. Classes will operate each Monday night of the week from 630 until 10 through the 15th of May. The class is open to all in terested persons in the Pamplin area for the construction or re pair of equipment. A fee of 1.- 50 will be made for each per son enrolling. In addition to the enrollment fee, a nominal char ge is made for welding rods and acetylene gas used. A lfre d Jamerson, a local farmer, will help with the in struction of the class, which is under the supervision of the De partment of Agricultural Edu cation at Appomattox County High School.
